Award.AwardTitle: BIGDATA: IA: DKA: Collaborative Research: Learning Data Analytics: Providing Actionable Insights to Increase College Student Success

Directorate.LongName: Direct For Computer & Info Scie & Enginr

Award.AbstractNarration:
The six-year higher-education graduation rate has been around 59% for over 15 years; less than half of college graduates finish within 4 years. This has high human, economic and societal costs. The National Research Council has identified a critical need to develop innovative approaches to improve student retention, graduation, and workforce-preparedness. The objective of this project is to develop new computational methods to analyze large and diverse types of education and learning data to help (a) discover successful academic pathways for students; (b) improve pedagogy for instructors; and (c) enhance student persistence and retention for institutions. The project outcomes are designed to help students select courses that fit their needs, capabilities, and learning styles, and are likely to lead to (faster) graduation; help instructors to better meet student needs; and give advisors and institutions the analytics needed to improve retention and persistence.

The proposed research will produce new dynamical system modeling, collaborative filtering, and multi-task learning methods. Modeling the evolution of a student's knowledge using a dynamical state-space system is a key innovation; the proposed research will develop novel collaborative system identification and collaborative Kalman filtering techniques for grade prediction. Technical innovations include supervised learning approaches for evolving datasets, such as linear and non-linear multi-task learning and collaborative multi-regression models with controlled grouping of the latent variables. These innovations will coalesce into three pilot applications: DegreePlanner for students, CourseInsights for instructors, and StudentWatch for academic advisors.

POR.DRECONTENT:
Learning analytics in higher education is an emerging research field that combines data mining, machine learning, statistics, and education on learning-related data, in order to develop methods that can improve the learning environment for learners, and allow educators and administrators to be more effective. 

The research on this project developed various algorithms and methodologies that encode what students are learning as they take courses, estimate students? grades in future courses, determine the order in which students should take certain courses, and determine the factors that lead to poor performance in specific courses. This project?s research allows higher educational institutions to deploy methods that identify the students? knowledge gaps and recommend appropriate courses, guide students towards registering for courses that are well-prepared for and are expected to do well them, determine personalized degree plans, and provide early advice and warnings to students that are at risk of not doing well. The collective benefits of these methods will be higher retention rates, timely graduate, and ultimately better undergraduate education. 

From a theoretical perspective, the research develop novel deep neural network-based methods for knowledge tracing and capturing intra-set correlations, it showed that every joint distribution of finite-alphabet random variables (e.g., course grades) can always be represented using a Bayes model, and that high-dimensional joint distributions can be reconstructed from lower-dimensional marginals, provided that the high-dimensional joint distribution exhibits low (tensor) rank. Additional innovations include the first result that guarantees unique tensor completion from regular (as opposed to random) samples, new and provably convergent algorithms for generalized canonical correlation analysis, and coupled matrix factorization tools for grade prediction. 

This project?s research has been published extensively, resulting in over 20 journal and conference publications, including two very popular tutorials, one on tensor decomposition for signal processing and machine learning, which remained among the top-100 downloads in IEEExplore for 2 years (and gathered over 350 citations), and another on nonnegative matrix factorization and its various generalizations. Four PhDs who graduated with primary support from this grant now work in academic and highly sought-after positions in industry, and several more PhDs who worked on this grant are well on their way to graduation.
